case_name: Union of India v. Maharaja Krishnagarh Mills Ltd.

facts.text: This is Civil Appeal No. 252 of 1956.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 252 of 1956. Appeal from the judgment and decree dated September 29, 1953, of the Rajasthan High Court  Jaipur Bench  in Civil Writ Application No. 28 of 1951.

facts.text: Appeal from the judgment and decree dated September 29, 1953, of the Rajasthan High Court Jaipur Bench in Civil Writ Application No. 28 of 1951.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and decree dated September 29, 1953, of the Rajasthan High Court  Jaipur Bench  in Civil Writ Application No. 28 of 1951. Gopal Singh and T. M. Sen, for the appellants.

facts.text: Judgment of the Court delivered on January 19, 1961 by SINHA, C. J.

anchor.surface_text: 1961. January 19. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by SINHA, C. J.-This appeal on a certificate granted by the Jaipur Bench of the High Court of Judicature for Rajasthan that the case involves a substantial question of law as to the interpretation of Arts. 277, 278, 294 and 295 of the Constitution of India and the case is a fit one for appeal to the Supreme Court under Art. 132 1  and also under Art. 133 1  c  of the Constitution of India is directed against the judgment dated September 29, 1953, of the High Court of Judicature for Rajasthan at Jaipur to the effect that the appellant, the Union of India, was number entitled to levy and recover arrears of excise duty on companyton cloth for the period April 1, 1949, to March 31, 1950, from the respondent, the Maharaja Krishnagarh Mills Ltd.

facts.text: The facts of this case have not been in dispute at any stage of the proceedings.

anchor.surface_text: The facts of this case, which have number been in dispute at any stage of the proceedings, may shortly be stated as follows.

facts.text: The respondent is a cloth mill located in Krishnagarh in District Jaipur in the State of Rajasthan.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent is a cloth mill located in Krishnagarh in District Jaipur in the State of Rajasthan. It had a stock of manufactured cloth on April 1, 1949, and also manufactured cloth during the period, April 1, 1949, and March 31,1950.

facts.text: Respondent had a stock of manufactured cloth on April 1, 1949, and manufactured cloth during April 1, 1949 to March 31, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: It had a stock of manufactured cloth on April 1, 1949, and also manufactured cloth during the period, April 1, 1949, and March 31,1950. In respect of such cloth an excise duty became payable under the Rajasthan Excise Duties Ordinance, 1949  XXV of 1949 , at rates set forth in the schedule to the Ordinance.

facts.text: Excise duty became payable on such cloth under Rajasthan Excise Duties Ordinance, 1949 (XXV of 1949).

anchor.surface_text: In respect of such cloth an excise duty became payable under the Rajasthan Excise Duties Ordinance, 1949  XXV of 1949 , at rates set forth in the schedule to the Ordinance. The sum of Rs. 1,56,291 odd became payable on that account out of which only a sum of Rs. 19,739 odd was paid to the Government of Rajasthan, thus leaving the sum of Rs. 1,36,551 odd outstanding against the respondent.

facts.text: Sum of Rs. 1,56,291 became payable, out of which Rs. 19,739 paid to Government of Rajasthan, leaving Rs. 1,36,551 outstanding.

anchor.surface_text: The sum of Rs. 1,56,291 odd became payable on that account out of which only a sum of Rs. 19,739 odd was paid to the Government of Rajasthan, thus leaving the sum of Rs. 1,36,551 odd outstanding against the respondent. After the Indian Constitution came into effect the Central Excise and Salt Act, 1944, and the rules framed thereunder were extended to the State of Rajasthan by s. 11 of the Finance Act of 1950.

facts.text: Central Excise and Salt Act, 1944 extended to Rajasthan by s.11 Finance Act 1950, effective April 1, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: After the Indian Constitution came into effect the Central Excise and Salt Act, 1944, and the rules framed thereunder were extended to the State of Rajasthan by s. 11 of the Finance Act of 1950. Hence, the duty became payable in respect of the cloth manufactured on and from April 1, 1950, under the provisions of that Act.

facts.text: Rajasthan Excise Duties Ordinance, 1949 promulgated by His Highness the Rajpramukh on September 5, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: It was also companytended that by virtue of s. 3 of Rajasthan Excise Duties Ordinance  XXV of 1949  promulgated by His Highness the Rajpramukh of Rajasthan on September 5, 1949, excise duty was levied on cloth and other articles produced and manufactured in Rajasthan on and after April 1, 1949, at the rates set forth in the first schedule of the said Ordinance.

facts.text: Agreement between President of India and Rajpramukh of Rajasthan on February 25, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: It was also companytended that in pursuance of Arts. 278 and 295 of the Constitution the President of India had entered into an agreement with the Rajpramukh of Rajasthan on February 25, 1950, whereby the parties agreed to accept the recommendations of the Indian States Finance Enquiry Committee, 1948-49

facts.text: Superintendent of Central Excise, Jaipur served notice dated February 16, 1951 demanding Rs. 1,36,551.

anchor.surface_text: In enforcement of that claim the Superintendent of Central Excise, Jaipur, served a numberice dated February 16, 1951, on the respondent demanding payment of the outstanding amount of Rs. 1,36,551 odd.

facts.text: Respondent filed writ petition in High Court of Rajasthan, Jaipur under Art. 226 against Union of India, Central Board of Revenue, Collector of Central Excise, Superintendent.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent thereupon filed a writ petition in the High Court of Rajasthan, Jaipur, under Art. 226 of the Constitution against  1  the Union of India,  2  the Central Board of Revenue, Delhi,  3  the Collector of Central Excise for Rajasthan, Delhi, and  4  the Superintendent of Central Excise, Jaipur, who are the appellants before us, praying for a writ of prohibition against them prohibiting them from imposing, levying or companylecting any tax or duty by way of excise as also for any appropriate direction, order or writ.

facts.text: Division Bench of Ranawat and Sharma JJ referred two questions to larger Bench on November 5, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: The matter was first heard by a Bench companysisting of Ranawat and Sharma, JJ., which, in view of the importance of the points involved in the case, referred the following two points for decision by a larger Bench by its judgment dated November 5, 1951

facts.text: Full Bench of Wanchoo C.J., Ranawat and Dave JJ delivered judgment on November 24, 1952 upholding contentions of petitioner (mill).

anchor.surface_text: The case was then heard by a Full Bench companysisting of Wanchoo, C.J., Ranawat and Dave, JJ. The judgment of the Court was delivered by the learned Chief Justice on November 24, 1952, in substance upholding the companytentions raised on behalf of the petitioner before the High Court, number respondent.

facts.text: High Court final judgment dated September 29, 1953 directing not to recover Rs. 1,36,551.

anchor.surface_text: the Bench, in pursuance of the opinion of the Full Bench, ordered by its judgment dated September 29, 1953, that a direction be issued against the opposite party number to recover from the petitioner the amount of Rs. 1,36,551-12 as per their numberice of demand of the 16th of February, 1950.

facts.text: Union of India obtained certificate from High Court for appeal to Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: The Union of India applied for and obtained the necessary certificate, as quoted above, from the High Court of Rajasthan. That is how the matter is before this Court.

facts.text: Rajasthan Gazette published Ordinance XXV of 1949 and Rules on Margashirsa Krishna 7, Saturday, Samvat 2006, notification dated September 15, 1949, authenticated by Law Secretary.

anchor.surface_text: We have examined the Rajasthan Gazette, the Hindi version of which is entitled Rajasthan Raj Patra published by authority of the Rajasthan Government dated Margashirsa Krishna 7, Saturday, Samvat 2006, companytaining the numberification dated Jaipur, September 15, 1949, the preamble of which states that Shriman Rajpramukh had made and promulgated the following Ordinance which was being published for the information of the public and it purports to have been authenticated by the Law Secretary, Sanyukta Rajasthan Sarkar.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds that authentication covers Ordinance and Rules.

anchor.surface_text: Under that authentication follows the Ordinance, XXV of 1949, dated September 5, 1949. The Ordinance goes to the end of page 169 and from the next page 170 ending with page 172 appear the Rules.

facts.text: Agreement incorporates recommendations of Indian States Finance Enquiry Committee 1948-49, taking over federal revenues including excise duties and arrears from April 1, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: The agreement thus incorporates as terms of the agreement the report of the Committee, the relevant portion of which is in these terms- With effect from the prescribed date, the Centre will take over all federal sources of Revenue and all federal items of expenditure in State together with the administration of the Departments companycerned. The Centre must also take over all current out standings  including pending assessments, refunds, and arrears , liabilities, claims, etc., and all productive and unproductive capital assets companynected with these Departments.

facts.text: Supreme Court allows appeal and sets aside High Court decision.

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons aforesaid, this appeal is allowed and the decision of the High Court set aside.

issues.text: Whether by virtue of Articles 278, 279 and 295 of the Constitution of India and the agreement entered into between the President of India and the Rajpramukh of Rajasthan on the 25th of February, 1950, the Union of India is entitled to levy and recover arrears of excise duty on cloth held in stock or manufactured before the 1st of April, 1950, in case excise duty thereon was payable to the State of Rajasthan under the provisions of the Rajasthan Excise Duties Ordinance No. 25 of 1949?

anchor.surface_text: Whether by virtue of Articles 278, 279 and 295 of the Constitution of India and the agreement entered into between the President of India and the Rajpramukh of Rajasthan on the 25th of February, 1950, the Union of India is entitled to levy and recover arrears of excise duty on cloth held in stock or manufactured before the 1st of April, 1950,

issues.text: Whether the publication of the Government notification by which the Jaipur Excise Rules were adopted under the provisions of the Rajasthan Excise Ordinance was sufficient publication within the meaning of s. 28 of the Rajasthan Excise Duties Ordinance No. 25 of 1949, and whether the publication of the aforesaid notification should be deemed to have been properly authenticated by authentication of the publication of the Ordinance. If not, whether want of authentication would have the effect of invalidating the said Excise Rules?

If not,

The Centre must also take over all current out standings  including pending assessments, refunds, and arrears , liabilities, claims, etc.,

But Art. 277 must yield to any agreement made between the Government of India and the Government of a State in Part B

arguments.claim: High Court's reasons for rejecting agreement invalid: agreement covers via report; overrides 277; duty leviable by Union

anchor.surface_text: The reasons given by the High Court for the companyclusion that in spite of Art. 278 read with the agreement aforesaid, the Union Government was number entitled to realise the arrears are- 1  that the agreement does number companytain any specific provision about levy and companylection of companyton excise duty in Rajasthan,  2  that the mere approval in the agreement of the principles set out in the report is number enough in view of Art. 277 ... In our opinion, numbere of these reasons aforesaid can stand in the way of the Union of India.

holdings.text: The authentication by the Law Secretary appearing on the first page of the Gazette as aforesaid was intended to govern not only the Ordinance in question but also the Rules which had been promulgated thereunder.

anchor.surface_text: It would thus appear that the authentication by the Law Secretary appearing on the first page of the Gazette as aforesaid was intended to govern not only the Ordinance in question but also the Rules which had been promulgated thereunder. Apparently, s. 28 of the Ordinance which ran- All rules made and notifications issued under this Ordinance shall be made and issued by publication in the Rajasthan Gazette.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Examination of Gazette publication shows preamble and authentication cover entire content including rules following ordinance; position of authentication immaterial if intent clear per s.28.

holdings.text: The formal requirements of s. 28 of the Ordinance V of 1949 were satisfied. Whether the authentication appears in the beginning of the notification or at the end of it is not material so long as it is clear on a reference to the publication in the Gazette that the matter is substantially covered by the authentication.

anchor.surface_text: Apparently, s. 28 of the Ordinance which ran- All rules made and notifications issued under this Ordinance shall be made and issued by publication in the Rajasthan Gazette. All such rules and notifications shall thereupon have effect as if enacted in this Ordinance - was understood to authorise such a mode of promulgation and authentication.

holdings.reasoning_summary: S.28 requires publication in Gazette; authentication at start covers rules as part of notification.

holdings.text: The High Court, therefore, was in error in coming to the conclusion that the authentication covered the Ordinance proper without the Rules framed thereunder. The correct conclusion from the record as it stands is that the authentication covers the entire notification including both the Ordinance proper and the Rules framed thereunder which became parts of the Statute.

anchor.surface_text: The authority that promulgated the rule having intended the signature of the Law Secretary appearing at the beginning of the publication as an authentication of the rules, we are of opinion that the formal requirements of s. 28 of the Ordinance V of 1949 were satisfied. Whether the authentication appears in the beginning of the notification or at the end of it is not material so long as it is clear on a reference to the publication in the Gazette that the matter is substantially covered by the authentication, whether appearing at the beginning or the end of the notification.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejects High Court's view; entire gazette entry authenticated as one.

holdings.text: Thus, on a construction of the provisions of Arts. 277 and 278, it is clear that in the absence of any agreement between the Government of India and the Government of a State specified in Part B, duties of customs which immediately before the commencement of the Constitution were being lawfully levied by the Government of such a State continue to be levied by that State until provision to the contrary is made by Parliament by law... But Art. 277 must yield to any agreement made between the Government of India and the Government of a State in Part B in respect of such taxes or duties, etc.

anchor.surface_text: Thus, on a construction of the provisions of Arts. 277 and 278, it is clear that in the absence of any agreement between the Government of India and the Government of a State specified in Part B, duties of customs which immediately before the commencement of the Constitution were being lawfully levied by the Government of such a State continue to be levied by that State until provision to the contrary is made by Parliament by law, notwithstanding that such a duty is mentioned in the Union List.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Harmonious construction: Art 277 saving clause yields pro tanto to Art 278 agreements; 278 overrides Chapter I Part XII including 277.

holdings.text: The agreement read with Art. 278, as already indicated, in terms, overrides the provisions of Art. 277... That a duty of the kind now in controversy on the date of the agreement after coming into force of the Constitution is leviable only by the Government of India even in respect of the State of Rajasthan is clear beyond all doubt. The Union List only, namely, entry 84 in the Seventh Schedule, authorises the levy and collection of the duty in question.

anchor.surface_text: That a duty of the kind now in controversy on the date of the agreement after coming into force of the Constitution is leviable only by the Government of India even in respect of the State of Rajasthan is clear beyond all doubt. The Union List only, namely, entry 84 in the Seventh Schedule, authorises the levy and collection of the duty in question.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Excise duty federal subject per Union List; agreement transfers arrears including pre-1950; overrides state levy under 277.

holdings.text: The combined operation of Arts. 277 and 278 read with the agreement vests the power of levy and collection of the duty in the Union of India.

anchor.surface_text: Neither the State List, List II, nor the Concurrent List, List III, contains any such authorisation. It is true that Art. 277 has saved, for the time being, until Parliament made a provision to the contrary, the power of the State of Rajasthan to levy such a duty, but that is only a saving provision, in terms subject to the provisions of Art. 278.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Agreement incorporates committee report taking over federal revenues, arrears from April 1, 1949.

holdings.text: It is clear, therefore, that the High Court was in error in holding that Art. 277 was any answer to the claim of the Government of India and should override the provisions of Art. 278 read with the agreement. On a proper construction of these provisions, in our opinion, the result is just to the contrary.

anchor.surface_text: Thus, the combined operation of Arts. 277 and 278 read with the agreement vests the power of levy and collection of the duty in the Union of India. It is only in the absence of an agreement like the one we have in this case that the Rajasthan Government could continue to levy and collect the duty in question.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejects High Court's view that 277 overrides agreement; agreement displaces 277 operation.

holdings.text: For the reasons aforesaid, this appeal is allowed and the decision of the High Court set aside.

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons aforesaid, this appeal is allowed and the decision of the High Court set aside.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative holdings entitle Union to arrears; reverses High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The authority that promulgated the rule having intended the signature of the Law Secretary appearing at the beginning of the publication as an authentication of the rules, we are of opinion that the formal requirements of s. 28 of the Ordinance V of 1949 were satisfied. Whether the authentication appears in the beginning of the notification or at the end of it is not material so long as it is clear on a reference to the publication in the Gazette that the matter is substantially covered by the authentication, whether appearing at the beginning or the end of the notification.
For the reasons aforesaid, this appeal is allowed and the decision of the High Court set aside.

anchor.surface_text: Thus, on a construction of the provisions of Arts. 277 and 278, it is clear that in the absence of any agreement between the Government of India and the Government of a State specified in Part B, duties of customs which immediately before the commencement of the Constitution were being lawfully levied by the Government of such a State continue to be levied by that State until provision to the contrary is made by Parliament by law, notwithstanding that such a duty is mentioned in the Union List.
For the reasons aforesaid, this appeal is allowed and the decision of the High Court set aside.
